content.content:
1→---
     2→title: "Webhooks"
     3→description: "Connect external systems to your agents using webhook endpoints"
     4→icon: "webhook"
     5→---
     6→
     7→Webhooks enable you to trigger xpander.ai agents from any external system that can make HTTP requests. Each agent has a unique webhook URL for programmatic interaction.
     8→
     9→## Accessing Your Webhook URL
    10→
    11→<Frame caption="Agent Builder Interface">
    12→![Agent Builder Interface](/static/images/screenshots/36DB40C0-7033-4F84-8CB8-EA1FAD14C561.png)
    13→</Frame>
    14→
    15→To find your webhook URL:
    16→1. Navigate to your agent in the AI Agent Workbench
    17→2. Click the "Webhook" trigger in the top of the graph
    18→3. The Webhook Configuration panel will open, providing:
    19→   - Ready-to-use code snippets
    20→   - Configuration instructions
    21→   - Testing capabilities
    22→   - Webhook management options
    23→
    24→<Frame caption="Webhook Configuration Interface">
    25→![Webhook Configuration Interface](/static/images/screenshots/AECAB014-E97A-4D2C-BEDF-64118F45BD4D.png)
    26→</Frame>
    27→
    28→## Making Webhook Requests
    29→
    30→### Required Parameters
    31→
    32→| Parameter | Type | Description |
    33→| --------- | ---- | ----------- |
    34→| `agent_id` | string | The unique identifier of your agent |
    35→| `source_node_id` | string | The starting node ID in your agent's workflow |
    36→| `x-api-key` | string | Your API key for authentication (header or query parameter) |
    37→| `asynchronous` | boolean | Whether to wait for completion (`false`) or return immediately (`true`) |
    38→
    39→### Request Body Options
    40→
    41→| Option | Type | Description |
    42→| ------ | ---- | ----------- |
    43→| `files` | file | One or more files to process (PDF, PNG, JPEG, GIF, WEBP) |
    44→| `prompt` | string | A text prompt to send to the agent |
    45→
    46→<Warning>
    47→When uploading files, you must send the actual files using `multipart/form-data`. Direct external URLs to files are not supported as inputs. The platform will generate secure presigned URLs for your agent to access the uploaded files.
    48→</Warning>
    49→
    50→### Content Types
    51→
    52→- **With files**: Use `multipart/form-data` (curl handles this automatically with `--form`)
    53→- **JSON only**: Use `application/json` with the appropriate header
    54→
    55→## File Handling
    56→
    57→### Supported File Types
    58→
    59→xpander.ai supports a variety of file formats:
    60→- Documents: PDF
    61→- Images: PNG, JPEG, GIF, WEBP
    62→
    63→### Uploading Multiple Files
    64→
    65→To process multiple files in a single request:
    66→
    67→```bash
    68→curl --location "https://webhook.xpander.ai?asynchronous=true" \
    69→--header "x-api-key: YOUR_API_KEY" \
    70→--form "prompt=Process these documents" \
    71→--form "files=@/path/to/first-file.pdf" \
    72→--form "files=@/path/to/second-file.pdf" \
    73→--form "files=@/path/to/image.png" \
    74→--form "source_node_id=YOUR_SOURCE_NODE_ID" \
    75→--form "agent_id=YOUR_AGENT_ID"
    76→```
    77→
    78→For large batches of files (10+ files), we recommend:
    79→1. Using asynchronous mode (`asynchronous=true`)
    80→2. Breaking uploads into multiple requests of 5-10 files each
    81→3. Using a dedicated file uploader with retry capabilities
    82→
    83→### File URL Mechanism
    84→
    85→When you upload files through the webhook:
    86→
    87→1. xpander.ai automatically handles storage of your files
    88→2. Your agent receives secure presigned URLs to access these files
    89→3. These URLs remain valid for 30 days after upload
    90→4. Files are accessible only to your organization's agents
    91→
    92→<Info>
    93→All uploaded files are stored securely on our platform. Your agent doesn't need to handle file storage or download logic - it will automatically receive properly formatted URLs to access the files.
    94→</Info>
    95→
    96→## Synchronous vs Asynchronous Requests
    97→
    98→### Synchronous Mode
    99→
   100→```bash
   101→curl --location "https://webhook.xpander.ai?asynchronous=false" \
   102→--header "x-api-key: YOUR_API_KEY" \
   103→--header "Content-Type: application/json" \
   104→--data '{"source_node_id": "YOUR_SOURCE_NODE_ID", "agent_id": "YOUR_AGENT_ID", "prompt": "What can you do?"}'
   105→```
   106→
   107→- HTTP request remains open until agent completes
   108→- Returns complete execution details and results
   109→- Best for immediate responses and short tasks
   110→
   111→**Response:**
   112→
   113→```json
   114→{
   115→  "result": {
   116→    "id": "9642f5dd-e535-465f-bdaf-89be6ecaa2d5",
   117→    "status": "completed",
   118→    "result": "I specialize in extracting text from image and PDF files using Optical Character Recognition (OCR) technology. If you provide me with a file in a supported format (pdf, png, jpeg, gif, webp), I can extract the text content for you.",
   119→    "source": "webhook"
   120→  }
   121→}
   122→```
   123→
   124→### Asynchronous Mode
   125→
   126→```bash
   127→curl --location "https://webhook.xpander.ai?asynchronous=true" \
   128→--header "x-api-key: YOUR_API_KEY" \
   129→--header "Content-Type: application/json" \
   130→--data '{"source_node_id": "YOUR_SOURCE_NODE_ID", "agent_id": "YOUR_AGENT_ID", "prompt": "What can you do?"}'
   131→```
   132→
   133→- Returns immediately while agent processes in background
   134→- Best for long-running tasks and large file processing
   135→- Allows your application to continue execution
   136→
   137→**Response:**
   138→
   139→```json
   140→{
   141→  "result": "Started"
   142→}
   143→```
   144→
   145→## Example: OCR Document Processing
   146→
   147→This example shows how to extract text from a document using the OCR agent:
   148→
   149→```bash
   150→curl --location "https://webhook.xpander.ai?asynchronous=false" \
   151→--header "x-api-key: YOUR_API_KEY" \
   152→--form "prompt=Extract text from this document" \
   153→--form "files=@/path/to/your/document.pdf" \
   154→--form "source_node_id=YOUR_SOURCE_NODE_ID" \
   155→--form "agent_id=YOUR_AGENT_ID"
   156→```
   157→
   158→<Info>
   159→The OCR agent handles multiple document formats (PDFs and images) and preserves formatting when possible, including tables and structured content.
   160→</Info>
   161→
   162→### Sample OCR Result
   163→
   164→```json
   165→{
   166→  "result": {
   167→    "id": "07d6f375-53e9-4aa3-a7af-c36ce99a07d8",
   168→    "status": "completed",
   169→    "result": "## Financial Statement\n\n## ACCOUNT SUMMARY FOR PERIOD ENDED SEPTEMBER 30, 2024\n\n| Description | Amount | Percentage |\n|------------|--------|------------|\n| Opening Balance | 50,000 | - |\n| Deposits | 25,000 | - |\n| Withdrawals | (10,000) | - |\n| Fees | (1,500) | 3% |\n| Interest | 1,200 | 2.4% |\n| Closing Balance | 64,700 | - |",
   170→    "source": "webhook"
   171→  }
   172→}
   173→```
   174→
   175→## Monitoring Webhook Activity
   176→
   177→xpander.ai provides a comprehensive monitoring interface for webhook calls:
   178→
   179→<Frame caption="Webhook Monitoring Interface">
   180→![OCR Agent Monitoring Interface](/static/images/screenshots/858B1698-A13F-4B6B-9ADB-71629B4BD261.png)
   181→</Frame>
   182→
   183→The monitoring dashboard displays:
   184→- Complete execution logs
   185→- File processing details
   186→- Performance metrics
   187→- Full request/response data
   188→
   189→## Common Use Cases
   190→
   191→<CardGroup cols={2}>
   192→  <Card title="Workflow Automation" icon="robot">
   193→    Integrate with platforms like Zapier, Make.com, or n8n to trigger document processing based on external events.
   194→  </Card>
   195→  
   196→  <Card title="Document Processing" icon="file-pdf">
   197→    Extract structured data from documents to automate data entry and analysis workflows.
   198→  </Card>
   199→</CardGroup>

file.content:
---
title: "Quickstart - CLI"
description: "Get started with xpander.ai and build your first AI agent"
icon: "terminal"
---

## Installation and Configuration

<Steps>
  <Step title="Install the CLI">
    Install the xpander CLI globally:

    ```bash
    npm install -g xpander-cli
    ```
  </Step>

  <Step title="Configure your credentials">
    Set up your API key and organization:

    ```bash
    xpander configure
    ```

    <Accordion title="Example configuration output">
    ```
    You need to configure your credentials to use the Xpander CLI.
    ? Would you like to configure your credentials now? Yes
    ? Enter your Xpander API key: IhPLk2Cu5BXw5BmVBhld3p31mTpAxC892pD6O5E3
    API Key: IhPL...O5E3 (first and last 4 characters shown)
    ✔ API key validation successful
    API key saved to profile "default".
    Organization ID will be auto-detected for you now...
    ⠏ Detecting organization ID...Organization ID detected: 8d185373-8b24-47a7-8607-3e9036b968bb
    Organization ID saved to profile "default".
    ✔ Organization ID detected: 8d185373-8b24-47a7-8607-3e9036b968bb
    Found 1 agent(s) in your organization.
    Set "default" as the default profile.
    Credentials stored at: /Users/david/.xpander/credentials
    Profile: default

    Configuration successful.
    ```
    </Accordion>
  </Step>
</Steps>

## Creating Your First Agent

<Steps>
  <Step title="Create a new agent">
    Create your agent using the CLI:

    ```bash
    xpander agent new
    ```

    <Accordion title="Example agent creation output">
    ```
    ✨ Agent Creation Wizard ✨
    ──────────────────────────────────────────────────
    Create a powerful AI agent for your organization
    ──────────────────────────────────────────────────

    ? What name would you like for your agent? my-first-agent
    ⠋ Creating agent "my-first-agent"...Creating agent in organization: 8d185373-8b24-47a7-8607-3e9036b968bb...
    ✔ Agent "my-first-agent" created successfully!

    🚀 Your Agent is Ready!
    ──────────────────────────────────────────────────
    Name:     my-first-agent
    ID:       4fe1163d-bb00-4837-9e25-6f82aed8038c
    Icon:     🚀
    Model:    openai/gpt-4.1
    ──────────────────────────────────────────────────

    ✅ Agent creation complete!

    ? Do you want to load this agent into your current workdir? Yes


    ✨ Initializing agent
    ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
    ℹ Agent my-first-agent retrieved successfully
    ? The current directory is not empty. Proceeding will override 'requirements.txt' and add or update xpander-related files (xpander_config.json, 
    agent_instructions.json, etc). Yes
    ✔ Agent initialized successfully
    ```
    </Accordion>
  </Step>

  <Step title="Configure environment variables">
    Create a `.env` file in the root directory with the following credentials:

    ```txt .env file
    XPANDER_API_KEY=your_xpander_api_key  # From the xpander login output
    OPENAI_API_KEY=your_openai_api_key
    OPENAI_MODEL_ID=gpt-4.1
    ```
  </Step>
</Steps>

## Working with Your Agent

With your agent created, you can now work with it in several ways:

1. **Using the SDK in your code**: Implement the agent loop and integrate with your application
2. **Stream events from the cloud**: Set up a handler to receive events from xpander.ai
3. **Deploy to the cloud**: Host your agent in the xpander.ai cloud

For detailed code examples and step-by-step implementation instructions, see our dedicated [Instrument & Run AI Agents](/docs/01-get-started/03-instrument-agents) guide.

---
title: "Module 2: SWE task management UI"
description: "Use a lightweight ChatGPT-Codex style UI to submit a coding task to your SWE agent"
icon: "desktop"
---

<Note>
In this module, we deploy a custom UI that is similar to the capabilities you get with ChatGPT-Codex, connect it to Agent Backend, and we will submit development tasks while we explore how the agent is working.
</Note>

**Goal**: Build a full-stack coding agent (Frontend and Backend) and task it to write an application and send a PR completely autonomously

## Step 1: GitHub Manual Fork

To submit a PR with your generated app to the apps-by-agents repository, first fork the repo:

1. Go to https://github.com/xpander-ai/apps-by-agents
2. Fork the repo to your GitHub account

## Step 2: Clone the frontend example app

We’ll start by cloning and installing the pre-built UI:

```bash
git clone https://github.com/xpander-ai/coding-agent-frontend-example-app.git
cd coding-agent-frontend-example-app
npm install
```

## Step 3: Configure environment variables

Copy the example .env file and populate it

```bash
mv .env.example .env
```

## Step 4: Connect the Frontend to the Agent Backend

In the frontend application, go to the `.env` file and fill in the following:

```env
# API Key - Available in CLI output
VITE_APP_API_KEY=your_api_key_here
# Agent ID - Available in CLI output
VITE_APP_AGENT_ID=your_agent_id_here
# Organization ID - Available in the CLI output
VITE_APP_ORGANIZATION_ID=your_organization_id_here
```

I am an autonomous Coding Agent, built with the [xpander-ai/coding-agent](https://github.com/xpander-ai/coding-agent) source code. As a self-driven software engineer, I am capable of generating, executing, and managing code through structured function-calling and a smart agent loop.\n\n## Modular Architecture\nMy architecture is modular, allowing for flexible extension and integration. Each component is designed to handle specific responsibilities, such as code generation, file management, version control, and external system interaction. This modularity ensures maintainability and scalability.\n\n## Schema-Driven Actions\nI support schema-driven actions, which means all my operations are defined and validated against explicit schemas. This guarantees that every action I perform is predictable, type-safe, and easy to audit.\n\n## Multi-Step Planning\nI am capable of multi-step planning, breaking down complex tasks into smaller, manageable subtasks. This enables me to tackle sophisticated development workflows while ensuring each step is executed reliably and in the correct order.\n\n## Context-Aware Memory\nMy context-aware memory allows me to retain and utilize relevant information throughout a session. I can reference previous actions, user instructions, and project state to make informed decisions and maintain continuity across tasks.\n\n## Connector-Based System Integration\nI integrate with external systems through a connector-based approach. ---
title: "Quickstart - CLI"
description: "Get started with xpander.ai and build your first AI agent"
icon: "terminal"
---

## Installation and Configuration

<Steps>
  <Step title="Install the CLI">
    Install the xpander CLI globally:

    ```bash
    npm install -g xpander-cli
    ```
  </Step>

  <Step title="Configure your credentials">
    Set up your API key and organization:

    ```bash
    xpander configure
    ```

    <Accordion title="Example configuration output">
    ```
    You need to configure your credentials to use the Xpander CLI.
    ? Would you like to configure your credentials now? Yes
    ? Enter your Xpander API key: IhPLk2Cu5BXw5BmVBhld3p31mTpAxC892pD6O5E3
    API Key: IhPL...O5E3 (first and last 4 characters shown)
    ✔ API key validation successful
    API key saved to profile "default".
    Organization ID will be auto-detected for you now...
    ⠏ Detecting organization ID...Organization ID detected: 8d185373-8b24-47a7-8607-3e9036b968bb
    Organization ID saved to profile "default".
    ✔ Organization ID detected: 8d185373-8b24-47a7-8607-3e9036b968bb
    Found 1 agent(s) in your organization.
    Set "default" as the default profile.
    Credentials stored at: /Users/david/.xpander/credentials
    Profile: default

    Configuration successful.
    ```
    </Accordion>
  </Step>
</Steps>

## Creating Your First Agent

<Steps>
  <Step title="Create a new agent">
    Create your agent using the CLI:

    ```bash
    xpander agent new
    ```

    <Accordion title="Example agent creation output">
    ```
    ✨ Agent Creation Wizard ✨
    ──────────────────────────────────────────────────
    Create a powerful AI agent for your organization
    ──────────────────────────────────────────────────

    ? What name would you like for your agent? my-first-agent
    ⠋ Creating agent "my-first-agent"...Creating agent in organization: 8d185373-8b24-47a7-8607-3e9036b968bb...
    ✔ Agent "my-first-agent" created successfully!

    🚀 Your Agent is Ready!
    ──────────────────────────────────────────────────
    Name:     my-first-agent
    ID:       4fe1163d-bb00-4837-9e25-6f82aed8038c
    Icon:     🚀
    Model:    openai/gpt-4.1
    ──────────────────────────────────────────────────

    ✅ Agent creation complete!

    ? Do you want to load this agent into your current workdir? Yes


    ✨ Initializing agent
    ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
    ℹ Agent my-first-agent retrieved successfully
    ? The current directory is not empty. Proceeding will override 'requirements.txt' and add or update xpander-related files (xpander_config.json, 
    agent_instructions.json, etc). Yes
    ✔ Agent initialized successfully
    ```
    </Accordion>
  </Step>

  <Step title="Configure environment variables">
    Create a `.env` file in the root directory with the following credentials:

    ```txt .env file
    XPANDER_API_KEY=your_xpander_api_key  # From the xpander login output
    OPENAI_API_KEY=your_openai_api_key
    OPENAI_MODEL_ID=gpt-4.1
    ```
  </Step>
</Steps>

## Working with Your Agent

With your agent created, you can now work with it in several ways:

1. **Using the SDK in your code**: Implement the agent loop and integrate with your application
2. **Stream events from the cloud**: Set up a handler to receive events from xpander.ai
3. **Deploy to the cloud**: Host your agent in the xpander.ai cloud

For detailed code examples and step-by-step implementation instructions, see our dedicated [Instrument & Run AI Agents](/docs/01-get-started/03-instrument-agents) guide.

</Step>
</Steps>

## Agent Templates

The xpander CLI provides several pre-built agent templates to accelerate development:

### Available Templates

<CardGroup cols={2}>
  <Card title="Agno Framework" icon="python">
    A Python framework for building multi-agent systems that enables integration of MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers as tools for AI agents. Ideal for complex workflows requiring multiple specialized agents.
  </Card>
  
  <Card title="Custom Templates" icon="template">
    Pre-configured agents for specific use cases including document processing, workflow automation, data analysis, and enterprise integrations.
  </Card>
</CardGroup>

### Template Benefits

- **Faster Development**: Start with proven patterns and configurations
- **Best Practices**: Templates follow established conventions and security guidelines  
- **Extensibility**: Easily customize templates for your specific requirements
- **Integration Ready**: Templates come with common tool integrations pre-configured

<Info>
Agent templates can be further customized through the [Agent Builder](/docs/02-agent-builder/01-adding-tools-to-agents) interface after creation.
</Info>

## Working with Your Agent

<Step title="Install the CLI">
    Install the xpander CLI globally:

    ```bash
    npm install -g xpander-cli
    ```

    <Info>
    The CLI will display its version number when you run commands. Recent versions include enhanced agent template support and improved workflow automation.
    </Info>
  </Step>

  <Step title="Configure your credentials">
    Set up your API key and organization:

    ```bash
    xpander configure
    ```

    <Accordion title="Example configuration output">
    ```
    You need to configure your credentials to use the Xpander CLI.
    ? Would you like to configure your credentials now? Yes

    Organization ID will be auto-detected for you now...

    Set "default" as the default profile.
    Credentials stored at: /Users/david/.xpander/credentials

    Configuration successful.
    ```

  </Step>

</Steps>

## Creating Your First Agent

<Steps>
  <Step title="Create a new agent">
    Create your agent using the CLI:

    ```bash
    xpander agent new
    ```

    <Info>
    During agent creation, you'll be prompted to select from available templates. Popular options include:
    - **Agno**: A Python framework for building multi-agent systems that allows integration of MCP servers as tools
    - **Custom Templates**: Pre-configured agents for specific use cases like document processing, workflow automation, and more
    </Info>

    <Accordion title="Example agent creation output">
    ```
    xpander-cli v0.0.37
    
    ✨ Agent Creation Wizard ✨
    ──────────────────────────────────────────────────
    Create a powerful AI agent for your organization
    ──────────────────────────────────────────────────

    ? What name would you like for your agent? my-first-agent
    ? Select a template: Agno (Multi-agent system framework)
    ⠋ Creating agent "my-first-agent"...Creating agent in organization: 8d185373-8b24-47a7-8607-3e9036b968bb...
    ✔ Agent "my-first-agent" created successfully!

    🚀 Your Agent is Ready!
    ──────────────────────────────────────────────────
    Name:     my-first-agent
    ID:       4fe1163d-bb00-4837-9e25-6f82aed8038c
    Icon:     🚀
    Model:    openai/gpt-4.1
    Template: Agno
    ──────────────────────────────────────────────────
    ```

Issue #75 has been successfully resolved! I've updated the CLI getting started documentation (`/workspace/sessions/737f7c31-78c4-4538-85e5-a4c51a76a14a/repo/docs/01-get-started/02-getting-started-02-cli.mdx`) with the missing information:

## Changes Made:

1. **Added CLI version information**: 
   - Added an info box explaining that the CLI displays version numbers when running commands
   - Updated the example output to show "xpander-cli v0.0.37" at the beginning

2. **Added agent template details**:
   - Added info box during agent creation explaining template selection
   - Updated example output to show template selection: "Agno (Multi-agent system framework)"
   - Added "Template: Agno" line in the agent creation output
   - Created a comprehensive "Agent Templates" section with:
     - Description of Agno as a Python framework for multi-agent systems with MCP integration
     - Information about custom templates for various use cases
     - Template benefits including faster development, best practices, extensibility, and integration readiness
     - Link to Agent Builder documentation for further customization

The documentation now provides clear guidance on CLI versioning and comprehensive information about available templates, specifically highlighting the Agno framework as mentioned in the GitHub issue.
